options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about writing and research
I gained research and writing skills and learned about my thesis topic area

I learned how to conduct a long-term research project independently, and how to start from scratch when working with primary source materials! The senior essay built up my confidence in my abilities to tackle a large project and see it to completion (largely) on my own.

This course teaches you how to do professional history research: Over the course of a year, you research and write a senior thesis on a topic of your choosing, working with a historian faculty advisor. It is a capstone to the history major at Yale.
Independent archival research

I learned how to write a long senior essay. This is incredibly valuable, both for the content of what I learned but more importantly for the process itself. I learned basics like long-term time management and in-depth research skills. I developed my skills both as a writer and a historian.
writing an extended piece, historical method, working with primary sources and critiquing secondary works, etc.

I learned how to successfully organize and plan the longest and most complex research paper I have ever attempted. I also worked closely with multiple medias in order to understand the subject completely!
Researching, analyzing and writing skills
I have sharpened a variety of invaluable skills, from archival research techniques to copy editing. This has been an amazing learning experience that I will never forget.
I gained a great deal of skills in performing independent research.

I think I learned the challenges of research and the stakes of writing history much better-- especially during the pandemic, with limited access to sources! Prof. Eller helped me approach those sources more creatively.
how to do an independent research project and write a 50+ page long paper.
I learned how to synthesize around a year's worth of research into a coherent long form paper, which was an invaluable experience.
I learned a lot about the research process, writing, professional-quality citations, and how to manage my time across a long-term project.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish we had a group of students meeting weekly outside of meetings with our advisors

Department deadlines help to provide accountability. Your senior essay experience will bevery much dependent on your advisor, your own interest in your topic, and your excitement about writing a senior essay.

It could be nice to have the first 10 pages due at the end of fall semester be an outline instead! While it was helpful to start writing, I also knew that I was going to discard those pages because I was too early on in my research (and ended up doing so).

The course is structured to facilitate independent research: That is both a blessing and a curse. The class gives you the space that you will need to research and write your thesis. But it also demands that you be organized and self-motivated along the way. Most people, like myself, have an amazing experience taking this class. If you pick a topic that you are genuinely curious about and one which you love researching  and if you have an adviser you get along with it will be the best course that you have taken at Yale. If you are not committed to your thesis topic or if you don't have a good relationship with your advisor, it can be a painful process. Luckily, you get to shape your entire destiny in this class. There is no single experience, and in the end, HIST 496 is really what you make of it.
The senior essay is an important part of the historian's learning process and thus should be kept. I wish the advisors were a bit more hands-on, but COVID partially prevented this.
The library was very accessible in a virtual setting and the librarians were incredibly helpful.

Strengths: I learned a lot about the topic
Weakness: I didnt receive super clear criticism
It's perfect!
There are no strengths or weaknesses. The senior essay is exactly what it needs to be.

the first semester of the senior thesis was not very helpful, especially with the frequent assignments. I barely used the assignments (like the primary source analysis) in my final paper, and instead spent a lot of time formatting, citing, etc. each assignment. For my own thesis, it would have been more helpful to start writing the actual thesis earlier, as opposed to the small assignments from the first semester.
N/a

I wish we could somehow meet with our grader a little after the due date for the first draft, or have our advisor grade our theses. I think writing, and to some extent, historical scholarship is very subjective and it would be nice to understand the preferences of our grader. It also took a very long time to get our reports back.

This course would benefit from in-person/virtual lectures. My advisor was not accessible and I could have used an actual environment for learning as opposed to individual work on the biggest project of my Yale career.

Though there is not a weekly meeting for this course, I think there could be a way to build more community among History majors in The Senior Essay. We could form writing groups or something for example maybe based on topic so people can build ideas off of one another and have a set time to work on their senior essays during the week, especially could be useful for those who struggle with time management.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A
None come to mind!
Doing archival research during a pandemic is tricky: Most people in HIST 496 adapted well using online archives, Zoom calls, and the like.
Very, very much appreciated the leniency with deadlines given the pandemic. Thank you so much for being so understanding.

The senior essay is far better before COVID. One needs to be able to conduct in person research and get their hands on documents. Unfortunately, this was not possible this year but we made do. The digitization of archives will make this easier for future generations.

I am thankful that Professor Gitlin adapted so smoothly to this virtual environment and still offered me stellar mentorship. I am also grateful for the History Department for being so understanding with us students. Your flexibility was much needed and deeply appreciated.
None, my advisor and I did a great job meeting.
N/a

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A
Highly recommend the two-term senior essay for any history major.

I would recommend doing a two-semester thesis instead of one! Having more time actually made it a less stressful process for me, and gave me more time to conduct primary source research and interviews than I otherwise would have had.

Yes, absolutely. If you are considering this course, you are likely a senior history major. Definitely take the two-semester senior essay (HIST 495 and HIST 496) rather than the one-semester senior essay. Two semesters give you the time that you need to properly research, engage with, and write your senior essay. On the whole, it is a more rewarding experience, and the end result is something that you will be prouder of. At the same time, it is easier to work on your (longer) essay over the full year. The two-semester essay also makes you eligible for various distinctions in the major.
its a requirement
It's required for majors, but I would encourage students to do the 2-semester thesis because one can produce more rigorous scholarship in two terms.
yes
Yes, of course. The senior essay has been one of the most rigorous, rewarding academic experiences of my Yale career.
It's required.
It's helpful for going about an entire independent research project on your own.
It is a requirement of the major.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Meeting with advisor over phone mostly
we never met as a class -- we just met with out advisors one on one. my advisor in particular only met with me a handful of times over the course of the year.
Senior essay.
Working on senior thesis; talking with advisor throughout.
Met with senior essay advisor virtually every two weeks.
Independent work and meeting with advisor
Archival research and writing; conversations with faculty advisor; review of secondary literature and primary sources.
Senior essay
Independent study
This is my thesis so I just had virtual meetings with my advisor
did not meet
senior thesis, virtual/in person discussions with advisor
Zoom meetings w/ advisor
Senior essay project - virtual meetings, in-person and virtual research
Independent study
This course is the senior essay. Most of the learning was independent, but my advisor and I had many zoom meetings to discuss progress and recommendations.
Independent research with an advisor
the class did not meet
meeting with thesis advisor every/every other week
This was a senior essay, so took the form of independent research with frequent meetings with advisor.
Meetings with Professor by phone.
Independent project
class did not meet weekly -- The Senior Essay was mostly composed of advisor meetings and an optional colloquium
